title: Books: Legacy Discovery
description: 図書館に所蔵されていない、または分類されていない希少本や自作本は、収集家や研究者が発見することはできません。

f6_assessments.q0: This is a great use case which could bring a new cadre of users to Cardano. Tracing ownership history of rare items is important for valuation and fraud. The proposer appears to have the knowledge and domain experience to be a great evangelizer for this project. Would you also include visual evidence in the file storage as well as metadata?
f6_assessments.q1: The proposer has great domain experience. It is not clear if the proposer has the technical expertise to successfully implement the proposal. It would be nice to have a more detailed plan on the technical side to be able to evaluate whether the $7500 set aside for developers is sufficient to successfully implement the proposal. Ideally the proposer would join with someone with the relevant technical experience to at least design the plan for a developer to implement.
f6_assessments.q2: The success criteria seem more focused around what the proposer will do, not how successful the project will be. It would be good to see a timeline for implementation of the technical side so progress can be measured there, and then some targets for the number of books whose metadata is uploaded by various time periods to measure success.

f6_assessments.q0: Building NFT metadata for limited edition books is a great idea. The lack of such a system is a great opportunity. Implementing such a system using the transaction metadata will fit the current challenge also create a positive impact for cardano.
f6_assessments.q1: The proposer says he has relevant experience in this domain, which is great, still, I would have loved to see some of the proposer's previous works in the proposal to get more insights about the proposer, which I would be expecting in future proposals as an improvement. Implementation plan looks great and achievable.
f6_assessments.q2: The breakdown provided by the proposer is sufficient to measure its success. The success of this would be of greater help in product authenticity.

f6_assessments.q0: I come to this assessment as someone who sees the value of preserving knowledge. This proposal is exceptionally clear, concise and reads as an exact answer to the Metadata Challenge. This problem is begging to be solved by Cardano NFTs and Metadata on the blockchain. The proposer has specified a distinct community that would use and benifit from this solution. The proposer is making this proposal with the blessing of an international organisation that represents his community. The proposer expresses openness to collaboration. IOHK has offered support for projects in this challenge and the proposer is requesting some technical know-how. This proposal is fitting like Cinderella's slipper into this challenge.
f6_assessments.q1:
This proposer inspires confidence in me that, if funded, the project would be executed successfully. The proposer has outlined a step by step roadmap and why this project would be impactful. In alignment with Cardano's mission and values this project intends to still be of utility in 500 years time using the power & immutability of the blockchain.
Because the proposal is so well written and the proposer references Lean Methodology it makes me think that the project would be undertaken with commitment and forethought. If this project is funded and has access to IOHK devs I think it will definitely be successful and useful in the world of rare and one of a kind books, preserving knowledge for us all. The budget requested is modest and the proposer has the backing of an international guild to undertake this project. I checked on the ADA Makerspace website and Kae is very responsive to questions and replies with thoughtful answers and information.
f6_assessments.q2: This proposal is highly auditable with the information provided. A roadmap with discrete steps is put forward and the proposer is cognisant of his/her own limitations. The proposer has referenced risk management and gives a selection of relevant metrics (both in development and live phases of project) by which the community could audit progress.

f6_assessments.q0: Proof of Existence of rare books is a use case that can be achieved by transaction metadata, however, the proposed solution was described with more focus in NFT and that may lead to some confusion if it fits in this Challenge. Since this Challenge involves the advice from IOHK expert team and the solution definitively requires proofs in metadata, the alignment to this Challenge will be more clear on the initial technical development phase.
f6_assessments.q1: The proposal addresses the plan in detail, providing comprehensive features, roadmap and future potential considerations. The proponent is also well engaged in the rare-book community that make the project more feasible. The only consideration is the lack of a developer in the team right now, however the advice of IOHK expert team will help on towards the goal of the project.
f6_assessments.q2: The proposal clearly includes deliverables and a timeline of main events. It also defines a success criteria for in the short and long term as well as some traceable metrics. Since the budget is mainly focus on developer cost, the auditability can be guaranteed.

f6_assessments.q0: This proposal is an excellent idea. It aligns very well with the metadata challenge. The proposer presents a valuable network effect providing tremendous exposure and scalability.
f6_assessments.q1: The proposer's experience as a bookbinder and author provides the necessary knowledge for success. A timeframe is provided but It is noted that a developer is budgeted for and required. Feasibility certainly appears present.
f6_assessments.q2: All metrics are auditable and available. No risks have been annotated. The only noticeable risk would be the developer acquisition. Would like to see the project expand beyond current expectations, the potential is there.
